chapterTitle: Some Lessons From Capital Market History

columns.text: In this problem, we will solve the percentage total return.

Using $\$58$ as the final price, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total percentage gain}&=\dfrac{\$1.45+(\$65-\$58)}{\$65}\\[15 pt]
&=0.13
\end{aligned}$$
This means that the total percentage gain is $0.13$ or $13\%$

The dividend yield refers to the percentage of the initial price that is given as dividend. To solve this, we can simply divide the dividend by the initial price:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Dividend yield}&=\dfrac{\text{D}_{\text{t}+1}}{\text{P}_\text{t}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Dividend yield}&=\dfrac{\$1.45}{\$65}\\[15 pt]
&=0.0223
\end{aligned}$$

The dividend yield for this is $0.0223$ or $2.23\%$

The capital gains yield refers to the percentage change between the initial price and the final price. We can do this by dividing the difference between the initial and final price to the initial price.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Capital gains yield}&=\dfrac{\text{P}_{\text{t}+1}-\text{P}_\text{t}}{\text{P}_\text{t}}\\

\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Capital gains yield}&=\dfrac{\$58-\$65}{\$65}\\[15 pt]
&=-0.107
\end{aligned}$$

The capital gains yield in this situation is $-0.107$ or $-10.7\%$

textbook.authors: Bradford D. Jordan, Randolph W. Westerfield, Stephen A. Ross
textbook.title: Fundamentals of Corporate Finance
